message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including stiffness in the morning and knee pain worse in the evening, suggest osteoarthritis. The firm nodules on the distal interphalangeal joints of the fingers also support this diagnosis. Pseudogout and gout usually present with acute, severe onset of joint pain, and septic arthritis would be associated with fever and joint erythema.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms match osteoarthritis, which commonly affects the distal interphalangeal joint and knee joint. The presence of firm nodules on the distal interphalangeal joints of the index, ring, and little fingers of both hands, known as Heberden’s nodes, are also consistent with osteoarthritis. Pseudogout and gout have different symptoms and causes. Septic arthritis would present with acute onset and more severe symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The stiffness in the morning lasting for around 10 minutes and the knee pain being worse in the evening suggest Osteoarthritis. The presence of firm nodules on the distal interphalangeal joints of the index, ring, and little fingers of both hands suggests Heberden's nodes, which are a characteristic finding in Osteoarthritis. Pseudogout and Gout are unlikely since there is no swelling or redness. Septic arthritis is unlikely due to the absence of joint effusion, erythema, and fever.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including morning stiffness and worsening knee pain in the evening, suggest Osteoarthritis. Firm nodules on the DIP joints of the index, ring, and little fingers are also characteristic findings of Osteoarthritis. Gout is more likely to affect the big toe and manifests as acute attacks of severe joint pain, rather than a progressive onset of symptoms. Septic arthritis is usually accompanied by fever and marked joint swelling, and pseudogout usually causes sudden and severe joint pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of joint pain and stiffness in the morning with improvement after several minutes suggest osteoarthritis. The patient’s alcohol intake is not high enough to cause gout symptoms. Septic arthritis would include fever and acute pain, and pseudogout would include calcium deposits visible on X-ray, which are not mentioned in the case. The firm nodules on the distal interphalangeal joints suggest osteophytes, which are characteristic of osteoarthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms are indicative of osteoarthritis, as there is pain and stiffness in the fingers and knees, and the knee pain is worse in the evening. The nodules on the distal interphalangeal joints of the index, ring, and little fingers are also characteristic of osteoarthritis. Pseudogout and gout typically present with acute joint pain, which is not described in the question. Septic arthritis would be unlikely given the chronic nature of the symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history and physical examination findings suggest osteoarthritis. Pseudogout and gout are usually characterized by sudden onset of pain and redness. Septic arthritis is characterized by pain, swelling, and fever. The nodules on the distal interphalangeal joints are consistent with Heberden's nodes, which are common in osteoarthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest osteoarthritis, which is characterized by morning stiffness that lasts less than an hour, and worsened pain in the evening. The firm nodules on the distal interphalangeal joints suggest Heberden’s nodes, which are associated with osteoarthritis. Pseudogout and gout usually present with sudden onset of intense pain and redness in one joint, and septic arthritis usually presents with fever and acute onset of joint pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history and physical examination suggest osteoarthritis, which is the most common cause of joint pain and stiffness in the hands and knees. Pseudogout and gout would typically cause more sudden and severe joint pain. Septic arthritis is less likely given the chronic nature of symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings suggest osteoarthritis, which commonly affects distal interphalangeal joints and is worse after periods of inactivity, such as sleeping. Gout and pseudogout typically cause acute attacks of joint pain, while septic arthritis typically causes redness, warmth, and severe pain in the affected joint.
